Universities in Leicester reassure students and staff after EU Referendum vote By IFrodsham | Posted: June 25, 2016 0 COMMENTS SHARES Paul Boyle and Dominic Shellard Universities in Leicester reassure students and staff after EU Referendum vote X 
Copy link to paste in your message / 
Universities in Leicester say they are supporting and reassuring staff and students who are uncertain about their futures following the EU Referendum vote. 
De Montfort University and the University of Leicester have thousands of European students and staff. 
EU students are entitled to similar loans as offered to their UK counterparts. 
Many academics also receive EU funding for research and study projects. 
Read more: Petition for second EU Referendum signed by more than 13,000 people in Leicestershire 
De Montfort University vice chancellor Professor Dominic Shellard spoke to 100 staff and students at a meeting on Friday to reassure them about the referendum result. 
He said: "De Montfort University recognises the contribution of international colleagues and students and urges them to speak openly if they have any concerns. 
"Universities must respond to divides in our country and do all we can to play our part in bringing the people back together." 
He said that the university would contact all non-UK applicants holding an offer to reassure them that their place was safe. 
De Montfort University 
De Montfort University has around 22,000 students. 
In the 2014/2015 academic year, the University of Leicester had 20,150 students and 3,605 full time members of staff. 
Neither university could confirm exactly how many EU nationals were among its students or staff. 
Read more: UK votes to leav e European Union with Leicestershire overwhelmingly backing Brexit - RECAP 
A report out in April revealed that in the East Midlands, EU students generated Â£143 million for the regional economy and 1,341 jobs. 
Professor Paul Boyle, president and vice-chancellor of the University of Leicester, said that the result was "shocking" and it was a "dark day for UK science". 
University of Leicester 
He said: "Now that the electorate has decided that we should leave, there needs to be some very careful negotiation about how we continue to collaborate freely with our European partners for the benefit of science, society and our economy. 
"We need to offer support to our European colleagues and students who are working and studying in the UK." 
Read more: Read more : EU referendum result: How did Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland vote? 
The university's registrar and chief operating officer Dave Hall said: "It's not the result we wanted, not a result which we think is in the long term interests of universities or the UK. It's very depressing. 
"We'll have to redouble our efforts to demonstrate that Leicester is a welcoming city and university to students from the EU." 
And Professor Iain Gillespie, Pro-Vice-Chancellor for Research and Enterprise, added: "We need to avoid isolation, including from EU financial support. It's time now to boost UK commitment to research excellence and reverse the decline in investment in science that we have seen over the past decade." 
EU nationals represented 6.4 per cent of all full-time students at British universities last year.
